While the risk of transmission from animals to humans is low, the CDC warns that it is still possible and that precautions should be taken to protect both pets and their owners. The agency is continuing to monitor the situation and provide updates as new information becomes available.

Super-TB is believed to have originated in China, where it has already claimed the lives of thousands of people. The situation is so dire that the Chinese government has declared a state of emergency and is working with the World Health Organization (WHO) to contain the outbreak. The symptoms of Super-TB are similar to those of regular TB, but they are more severe and can lead to death within days. The disease is resistant to most antibiotics, making it difficult to treat. The WHO has called for urgent action to contain the outbreak and prevent the spread of Super-TB. They have urged governments and health organizations to step up efforts to diagnose and treat the disease. As the world commemorates World TB Day, it is clear that the fight against TB is far from over.
